intro: Abutilon microspermum, commonly known as the woolly abutilon, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of about 1 to 2 meters. The plant features soft, fuzzy leaves and produces showy, lantern-shaped flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and red. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often cultivated as an ornamental plant. The fruit is a capsule that splits open to release small, hairy seeds.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon microspermum is primarily native to South America, specifically Brazil. It is found in the states of Pará, Amazonas, and Maranhão. This plant thrives in humid tropical environments, often in lowland areas with rich soil. It is commonly found in secondary forests and along riverbanks. Its distribution is closely associated with the Amazon Basin and surrounding regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon microspermum was mainly introduced to the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive, lantern-shaped flowers and fuzzy foliage. Despite its aesthetic appeal, it has since become invasive in some areas, outcompeting native vegetation. The plant thrives in moist, disturbed soils and can spread rapidly through seed dispersal. Its introduction has raised concerns among ecologists about its potential impact on local ecosystems.
